diff_hunk:
@@ -44,16 +44,27 @@ def will_write(self, filename):
                             "before running the generators")
         self.filenames.add(filename)
 
+    def _write_if_changed(self, filename, contents):
body:
Nope, Makefile knows how to do this correctly.

```
MacBook-Pro-97:make-restat ezyang$ cat Makefile
out: in
	if ! [ -e out ]; then touch out; fi

out2: out
	cp out out2
MacBook-Pro-97:make-restat ezyang$ touch in
MacBook-Pro-97:make-restat ezyang$ make out2
if ! [ -e out ]; then touch out; fi
cp out out2
MacBook-Pro-97:make-restat ezyang$ make out2
make: `out2' is up to date.
MacBook-Pro-97:make-restat ezyang$ touch in
MacBook-Pro-97:make-restat ezyang$ make out2
if ! [ -e out ]; then touch out; fi
```

In fact, the reason why Chrome build system did the no-touch strategy in the first place was because they were originally using CMake (and thus make) for builds.
